sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• usual dose, 200 mg ORALLY/IV infusion over 1 hour once daily for 6 days
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue, Acute: missed dose, administer as soon as possible, up to 8 hours before next scheduled dose; if less than 8 hours before next dose, wait until next scheduled dose

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and efficacy not established in patients younger than 18 years

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono: switching routes from IV to oral: no adjustment necessary

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue, Acute

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: specific contraindications have not been determined

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Gastrointestinal:
  • -- clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea has been reported, including cases occurring more than 2 months after administration; evaluate and institute appropriate medical management if suspected or confirmed
  • Hematologic:
  • -- consider alternative therapies in patients with neutropenia (less than 1000 cells/mm(3))

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea (4%), Nausea (8%), Vomiting (3%)
  • Neurologic:Dizziness (2%), Headache (6%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Tachycardia (less than 2%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Clostridium difficile colitis (less than 2%)
  • Hematologic:Neutropenia (0.5%)
  • Neurologic:Peripheral nerve disease (1.2%)
  • Ophthalmic:Disorder of optic nerve (0.3%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Tedizolid phosphate is the prodrug of tedizolid, an oxazolidinone antibiotic, which inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 50S subunit of the bacterial ribosome.

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Tmax, Oral, Tedizolid: 3.5 hours
  • Tmax, IV, Tedizolid: 1.2 hours
  • Bioavailability, Oral: 91%
  • Effects of food: no change in AUC

sub.title: Distribution
sub.mono:
• Tedizolid, Protein binding: 70% to 90%
  • Tedizolid, Vd: 67 to 80 L

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Feces: 82% is excreted primarily as inactive conjugate; less than 3% is unchanged tedizolid
  • Renal: 18% is excreted primarily as inactive conjugate; less than 3% is unchanged tedizolid
  • Dialyzable: No

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    for IV use only; do not administer via intra-arterial, IM, intrathecal, intraperitoneal, or subQ
  • Intravenous
    • vials intended for single use only
    • only reconstitute vial with 4 mL sterile water for injection; may gently swirl and invert vial to aid reconstitution, but avoid shaking during and after reconstitution
    • further dilute with 250 mL of NS ONLY; do not dilute with lactated Ringer or Hartmann solution
    • administer only as IV infusion over 1 hour; do not administer via IV push or bolus
    • do not mix or infuse simultaneously with other drugs or additives during administration
    • total storage time from reconstitution of vial to administration should not exceed 24 hours regardless of storage method
  • Oral
    administer with or without food

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono: improvement in acute bacterial skin and skin structure infections indicates efficacy

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
Sivextro
  • Intravenous Powder for Solution: 200 MG
  • Oral Tablet: 200 MG

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Side effects may include nausea, diarrhea, vomiting, headache, and dizziness.
  • Instruct patient to report severe watery or bloody diarrhea, even occurring 2 months after the last dose.
  • Advise patient of the importance for completing the entire course of therapy.
  • Instruct the patient to take the missed dose as soon as possible unless the next scheduled dose is in less than 8 hours. In this case, skip the missed dose and resume with the next scheduled dose.
